column2:
To the Sea, to the Sea! The white gulls are crying,
The wind is blowing, and the white foam is flying.

column1: '''Gulls''' or '''mews''' were birds found on all shores in [[Arda]].
Gulls were common in all sea-bordering lands (perhaps especially abundant on the cape of [[Ras Mewrim
column2: Bar-in-Mŷl]], the "Home of the Gulls", in the land of the [[Falas]]<ref name="QaE"/>), and for that, they were often attributed to [[Ossë]].<ref name="Fall">{{LT2
column3: III}}</ref> The [[Teleri]] that dwelt in the [[Havens]] were very fond of them, and their mewing welcomed [[Tuor]] to their land.<ref>{{UT
column4: 1}}</ref> They were also known in [[Númenor]]<ref name="AaE">{{UT

column1: Their association with the sea caused a great sense of longing for the journey to [[Valinor]] among [[Elves]] that were not familiar with their sound. One of those was [[Legolas]].<ref name="tLD"/>

column2: swan]] or gull-like feathers on their helmets.<ref name="Fall"/> The [[Lindar]] were at one point considered the "Lords of the Gulls" among many other names.<ref>{{LR
Etymologies]]'', one [[Noldorin]] and one [[Quenya]] word for "gull" appear, both from the same root: ''[[maew]]'' and ''[[maiwë]]''.<ref>{{LR
column4: Root]] [[MIW]])</ref> A later recorded [[Sindarin]] word is ''[[mŷl]]'',<ref name="QaE">{{WJ

column1: In manuscripts related to the ''Etymologies'' Tolkien also experimented with the Noldorin form ''cuen'', glossed as "small gull, petrel".<ref>{{VT

In the story ''[[Roverandom]]'', a seagull named Mew brings the dog Rover to the moon. On their way, Mew stops to visit other sea-birds, among them the "''oldest and most important of all the Blackbacked Gulls''".<ref>{{HM
